text: in this lecture I'm gonna really quickly
talk about a concept called ion pairing
now ion pairing is the momentary
aggregation of electrically charged ions
found in a concentrated solution of two
or more compounds now to really grasp
what we mean by ion-pairing let's create
a solution and see what happens within
our solution so let's mix liquid water
and solid sodium chloride and see what
happens
well once we mix them the sodium
chloride dissociates and forms ions so
we have a bunch of polar water molecules
separated by ions at any given time two
of these ions might be separated by
solid water molecule and at this point
they can't interact with one another
because of this separation however at
another place the solid molecule the
water molecule might not separate them
and at this point because of their
proximity the ions will form an ion pair
and this is only for the moment imagine
two ions floating or flying around in
the liquid right eventually they will
get close to each other and when they
get close to each other they will form
that momentary bond but it's only for
the moment because and they're traveling
they will attract and will continue to
travel so eventually they will break so
they travel attract their break and it's
only for the moment and that's the
difference between an ion pair and a
ionic bond and ionic bond is not for the
moment it stays it exists if this sodium
chloride is left untouched it will
continue the ionic bond will continue to
exist but in this case the ion pair only
exists for a moment now ion pairing does
not exist in an ideal solution and
that's because in an ideal solution by
definition all the ions are separated
from one another by solvent molecules so
no attraction between two ions exists so
I am pairing
exist in non ideal conditions now if you
if you want to see why I appear is
important and where it's applied check

point elevation and melting point

something called Von Hoff factor
